4917AF90E88743CBB6CE82E07FB21907.description: LA11.E.41: acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression

A4AAE3F813F6438D9C7AB6F5A8135765.description: LA11.E.40.b: analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations

DFCCD4697F314D95897763B55290C0EB.description: LA11.E.40.a: interpret figures of speech (e.g., hyperbole, paradox) in context and analyze their role in the text

90C2E3582ABE4682B4D4459DEDFC6272.description: LA11.E.40: demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings

1E0FD82029944E429733B2CF8EF25C14.description: LA11.E.39.e: verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary)

FB44BDB8AAB849109EC546CE6D9F6458.description: LA11.E.39.d: consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, or its etymology, or its standard usage

7C54729B2C3C4DDE8F30F7BEC3AE42CC.description: LA11.E.39.c: identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., conceive, conception, conceivable)

DAED2FFE3FAC462BACDAE212EF420C1C.description: LA11.E.39.b: use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin roots as clues to the meanings of words or phrases (e.g., chronology, chronometry, chronometer)

2BDE4248890F498DB535DE1E29A9E0AB.description: LA11.E.39.a: use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase

E410ED9397B74CC1B1E25AD486A8DED8.description: LA11.E.39: determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 11-12 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies

5F5DF97BD7854AE0940BA3E2C3EE3529.description: LA11.E.38.a: vary syntax for effect, consulting references (e.g., Tufte's Artful Sentences) for guidance as needed; apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts when reading

CD0B2909587849BE8A55B867ACF2134F.description: LA11.E.38: apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening

4690C43E674E4B139496B97DA2F96E94.description: LA11.E.37: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing

D0A5A02824EF476C8F2F97A48F9443B8.description: LA11.E.36.b: resolve issues of complex or contested usage, consulting references (e.g., Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, Garner's Modern American Usage), as needed

BB5E66DABE2948D7896E93A5767C4D75.description: LA11.E.36.a: apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and is sometimes contested

CC310E8082CB4949A7DBD3D4DB37EA9A.description: LA11.E.36: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking

9A1F16395CFD44098D8734CB15612D97.description: LA11.D.35: adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal English when indicated or appropriate

EBAC834920BF4D318704DEAF05D240A4.description: LA11.D.34: make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest

AD4B8B821A9B4BC3A14F2421FD6A8DF3.description: LA11.D.33: present information, findings, and supporting evidence, conveying a clear and distinct perspective, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, alternative or opposing perspectives are addressed, and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and a range of formal and informal tasks

7BB7BFA57EBC40EC847911485363A058.description: LA11.D.32: evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used

D4E12FED0AFF449F9AC3ACDFA5A6DA00.description: LA11.D.31: integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, and orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data

CE42101C199443CC997008A07F0AF950.description: LA11.D.30.d: respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives; synthesize comments, claims, and evidence made on all sides of an issue; resolve contradictions when possible; and determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the investigation or complete the task

742A94D2316B4CF9810F0A41AF261AFE.description: LA11.D.30.c: propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and evidence; ensure a hearing for a full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and creative perspectives

FDB8A018CD5D4E638FC95F3C14EB8930.description: LA11.D.30.b: work with peers to promote civil, democratic discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish individual roles as needed

F4B8E84C41D04C6DA0268280627DC24A.description: LA11.D.30.a: come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas

B596DADE336E4CB6BBBB9615FDEE54EB.description: LA11.D.30: initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (e.g., one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 11-12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively

394FE2B9CDD6461B97F43AD9BFB0F572.description: LA11.C.29: write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences

AEB4E2DA7C624BBF9ECFF6F868DCB68F.description: LA11.C.28.g: establish connection among observations made in the text in order to support critical analysis and reflection

364381E2D48D4AD087A5AC3897125C9F.description: LA11.C.28.f: produce a written reflection to an informational text that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

6A27809A07D6446A826DC67719FAEE55.description: LA11.C.28.e: produce a written reflection to literature and literary nonfiction that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

3E824B9E3D8C4F538F7B8AB9BECA2565.description: LA11.C.28.d: produce a written critical analysis of an informational text that draws evidence from the text

A371F175A4004017B1C1EDCA94AB12F3.description: LA11.C.28.c: produce a written critical analysis to literature and literary nonfiction that draws evidence from the text

E2EF8BB3AB8146A2812827AA895B0626.description: LA11.C.28.b: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to informational and US seminal texts

0AF92CAE0C2B4763992CB0D64666889D.description: LA11.C.28.a: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to literature and literary non-fiction (e.g., demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth-, and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics)

68740CD0959E47F59B70A714D5302A52.description: LA11.C.28: draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

8ABC627E90E742549026A066D18E4746.description: LA11.C.27: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citations

70AD22F12FF74688BAFD6AC6D25ADEA3.description: LA11.C.26: conduct short, as well as more sustained, research projects to answer questions (including self-generated questions) or solve problems; narrow or broaden the inquiries when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subjects, demonstrating understanding of the subjects under investigation

0F67A427C4764AE7A2817939D1818050.description: LA11.C.25: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

53AB9501267F4C48A1064FC528851330.description: LA11.C.24: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

16076865898144D09109F5FE9FF39D39.description: LA10.C.23: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

A6582980E2D14E06BD53F0802594616C.description: LA11.C.22.e: provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative

477851C335EC45B4B3C25CDBAA0BD348.description: LA11.C.22.d: use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters

0EEAEAD022BA499C834B03F26C1AA869.description: LA11.C.22.c: use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution)

D769DB378A1B4CF9BA539AF36C895589.description: LA11.C.22.b: use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters

6F3DBD68600C494C8377758321C017AE.description: LA11.C.22.a: engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events

2C28D33194A44F55975BFB7B306EF322.description: LA11.C.22: write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences

A44DECE728CE4EA6858C7CC44C929E82.description: LA11.C.21.g: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

2B0AB665EE2B4CE78BF5A55DAB69D34B.description: LA11.C.21.f: use documents to clarify details or support claims

75BFD6FB136E477EADA086EFC4DDB754.description: LA11.C.21.e: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

45651FDBB4BB4308AB6B4AA4BE4628E5.description: LA11.C.21.d: use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic

0C747C78071F4799AE5D70C1BD7AA7E8.description: LA11.C.21.c: use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

FBBE3259664A4F07AECF72B5CE65FB7C.description: LA11.C.21.b: develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

565647D3921843F1998D573810501BAE.description: LA11.C.21.a: introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

DF4B9A8D974D45298CC30A2BF32FA07F.description: LA11.C.21: write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content

2F96E1A530484DFB9CDF46601FA0A7D2.description: LA11.C.20.e: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented

B3B8DB2A8CD14A7E920C7F6A690AF142.description: LA11.C.20.d: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

1C69A10A0E4E4D9880218F92563035BA.description: LA11.C.20.c: use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

95991B882DC54AF3BCFA642B37D135BA.description: LA11.C.20.b: develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

FBF8A74EFD6046548DDF4FE78B1C519B.description: LA11.C.20.a: introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

D3401C6C57BB46A7BA5D159746D48EBD.description: LA11.C.20: write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence

0258431F619241D6B6AE211B380CE473.description: LA11.B.18.a: relate a literary work to primary source documents of its literary period or historical setting

6CF8D27BDB724B79A72342187D4BDD8A.description: LA11.B.18.a: relate a literary work to primary source documents of its literary period or historical setting

4BDEAFAD809143AAB78C774EE60C4741.description: LA11.B.18: analyze foundational U.S. documents (and comparable documents for British literature, American literature, and Multicultural literature) of historical and literary significance (including The Declaration of Independence, the Preamble to the Constitution, The Bill of Rights, and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address) for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features

EEFBE943DD364F64BBAC1126547CFDE2.description: LA11.B.17: delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist presidential addresses)

DD20089CFBAC4F13BB69CAAF11FC8243.description: LA11.B.16: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words in order to address a question or solve a problem

A66218EDCA57493794961D8A54E0E977.description: LA11.B.15: determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text in which the rhetoric is particularly effective, analyzing how style and content contribute to the power, persuasiveness, or beauty of the text

5A479A73A3A0428FBBCBDA3B9A54EBD3.description: LA11.B.14: analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging

F3ECC36560334D97B34BE75418AC9628.description: LA11.B.13: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines 'faction' in Federalist No. 10)

EABD1B764AF14E47BAFE0E4390CAEB41.description: LA11.B.12: analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text

5E035C34DB1749ADB19CD2E781FFA888.description: LA11.B.11: determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text

47D051F135DB4FB9A278CD9DE9339938.description: LA11.B.10: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain

051F76DAE557459BA1AD6A7988C1A0F8.description: LA11.A.9.a: analyze the structures and elements of American literature

9BAAEA9B2ABC4163B77A1F974FB15774.description: LA11.A.9: read and comprehend literature and literary nonfiction, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 11-12 CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range, by the end of grade 11

1D3ED34819D84FC9A12DF7137CF1C512.description: LA11.A.8: demonstrate knowledge of 18th, 19th, and early 20th-century foundational works (of American literature, British literature, world literature, or multicultural literature), including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics

07A1468832BD409A9D69B3CCA4DE4B3F.description: LA11.A.7: analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text (Include at least one play by Shakespeare and one play by an American dramatist)

159BE7BD4A7F4A09B892B2B53731C894.description: LA11.A.6: analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement)

71D847C458984A7FBD8E937B3F57D4AB.description: LA11.A.5: analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic resolution) contribute to its overall structure and meaning as well as its aesthetic impact

D9862D10681A4970A24C018ED45BA9AB.description: LA11.A.4: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful (include Shakespeare as well as other authors)

BBDE594D40DD42F19CDD487E61B68281.description: LA11.A.3: analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed)

389BD8BFFDA042E9BC5FB18BCD61465A.description: LA11.A.2: determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text

8B2AD2836C824E2FA5114DFAA2BD0970.description: LA11.A.1: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain
